documents.title: that 's it for today !
text: many thanks to david and to everyone who posted questions .
until next time !
guardian contributor davidoyelowo 24 september 2015 12:43pm this has been fun - i hope you all enjoy my new film captive .
it opens tomorrow , september 25 .
misterfrisky asks : i caught you recently in the paperboy ( ok maybe not a perfect film but nice to see a director taking chances , being experimental in this day and age .
i enjoyed it ) .
i liked the reveal of your character , and the it came as a shock/surpise when you switched accents ( and vocal delivery ) .
do you feel that the situation applies today , where maybe an outsider would get preferential treatment over a young black local ( for instance ) , a false air of mystery , maybe ?
( i know i 'm addressing this to a british actor making great inroads in the us , so i mean no personal inference and wish you the best of luck ) .

guardian contributor davidoyelowo 24 september 2015 12:42pm what my character in the paperboy was doing is what is known as code-switching , to a greater or lesser degree we all do that in life , to survive in different environments .
the need to survive different environments gets a little more intense depending on how marginalised you feel as an individual .
as a british actor , working in hollywood , i know this all too well .
in america , there is a misguided notion that you are more intelligent for having a british accent ; at times , that 's useful , and at times it 's not .
especially when you 've just done something very dumb .
moody54 asks : who was your favourite section chief from spooks ?
not including your own tom quinn .
guardian contributor davidoyelowo 24 september 2015 12:38pm if i ca n't have tom quinn , then i ca n't answer your question .
steff clarke asks : david , why do dogs wall around in circles before lying down ?
guardian contributor davidoyelowo 24 september 2015 12:37pm i imagine they lie down because they 've gotten quite dizzy .
vammyp asks : do you like quiche ?
if so , what kind of quiche ?
guardian contributor davidoyelowo 24 september 2015 12:36pm i like any quiche as long as the crust is crunchy .

lee31 asks : congratulations on your performance in selma , which was top draw is the lack of well written parts for british black actors here in the uk , the reason we see so many appearing in us film & televison ?
guardian contributor davidoyelowo 24 september 2015 12:35pm it 's not just the lack of well-written parts , it the lack of parts , period .
soitbegins asks : who is your favourite writer ?
guardian contributor davidoyelowo 24 september 2015 12:35pm shakespeare .
no actor before or since has written better dialogue for the actor .

openears asks : there 's lots of chatter about idris elba being the next bond and the first black bond , but in my opinion there is already a black bond and it 's your character edward ekubo in complicit your character really is a bond of our times , a real portrayal of what it must be like as an mi5 agent - do you have any plans to revive this character ? ?
also huge congrats on selma , a stunning performance .
guardian contributor davidoyelowo 24 september 2015 12:34pm thank you .
having done spooks , which was a bit like doing bond for the telly , complicit , in which i played edward ekubo , was more of what it was really like to be a spy .
i love that i got to play the glamourous side and the real side - i 'll leave the movie side to idris .
the real side is just normal , pen-pushing and grey - not a single car exploding .
unclearleo asks : i 've heard that the hardest role that a young , black actor can take on is blanche dubois .
would you consider this role if offered , or would the age thing be too much of a hurdle ?
guardian contributor davidoyelowo 24 september 2015 12:32pm i 'm game .
christianround asks : do you feel you should have got an oscar nom for selma ?
guardian contributor davidoyelowo 24 september 2015 12:32pm it would have been nice .
kwamiodoom asks : i 'm a young black actor .
is it worth me sticking with the british industry or should i get started on my american accent now ?

guardian contributor davidoyelowo 24 september 2015 12:31pm get started on your american accent because you never know - you may end up doing an american play at the royal court or a big american film in la .
giglover01 asks : what is it about a script that makes you want the part ?
guardian contributor davidoyelowo 24 september 2015 12:30pm if when i 'm reading it i feel i do n't know how to play the part , that 's what makes me want to play the part .
theshiftyshadow asks : do you prefer building sandcastles or snowmen ?
guardian contributor davidoyelowo 24 september 2015 12:29pm sandcastles .
i hate the cold .
jo allan asks : how have you found the transition from stage to screen ?
do you want to focus on one rather than the other ?

guardian contributor davidoyelowo 24 september 2015 12:29pm i have found that it is much better to transition from stage to screen because so much of what you learn from stage is applicable to the screen .

firstly , doing a play night after night helps hone your craft - that comes in very handy when you 're on a film set and having to put a character together very quickly , under very pressurised circumstances .
going the other way around , from film to theatre is tricky because to act on stage , your whole body need to be physically prepared and able to project your character .
on a film , it 's all about the eyes .
secondly there is a muscle memory you develop by doing stage of what the truth feels like .
you can tell by the audience 's reaction instantly when you 're not being truthful on stage .
knowing what that feels like helps you in film when the only thing reacting to you is an inanimate object called a camera .
calum langan asks : will you be the next actor to play dr who and james bond at the same time ?
guardian contributor davidoyelowo 24 september 2015 12:25pm no !
but it 's been incredible to see the reaction to me playing james bond in an audiobook .

it leaves me full of hope that the entertainment industry will listen to the audience 's desire to see people of colour playing roles that are not necessarily race-specific but are heroic and iconic .
giglover01 asks : is there any part of your life that you would revisit and change ?
guardian contributor davidoyelowo 24 september 2015 12:24pm i made some very questionable fashion decisions as a teenager .
one of them involved baggy tracksuit bottoms and dungaree shorts .
the less said about that the better .
isayast asks : how does your faith play an ongoing role in your career .
specifically in how you select the roles you choose to play ?
as a man of faith and current student at lamda , this is something that i 'm constantly processing as i think about my forthcoming transition out of school .
guardian contributor davidoyelowo 24 september 2015 12:23pm before i play a role , i pray about it .
thankfully god has good taste .
so my choice of roles are very much governed not just by what i deem to be morally right or wrong , but what feels spiritually right .
a common factor i have found in the roles i feel led to play is that they always show that light ultimately overwhelms the darkness .

documents.title: `` shonda rimes is a black woman putting on screen the life she leads . that 's what we do n't have in the uk ''
text: fabian ashun asks : viola davis ( a beautiful beautiful women ) has become the first african american actress to win a best actress primetime emmy award .
what do you think of her speech , which opened with a quote from harriet tubman : in my mind , i see a line .
and over that line , i see green fields and lovely flowers and beautiful white women with their arms stretched out to me , over that line , but i ca n't seem to get there no how .
i ca n't seem to get over that line .

also living in london seeing the diversity do you think there be will a day when we will have something alike , turn on terrestrial tv and see the same diversity on the streets of london as on the tv ?
guardian contributor davidoyelowo 24 september 2015 12:20pm i was there for viola 's speech , and what she was saying is indicative of what has been being said for many years now .
the difference the other night was that the other night was that she was given a big platform to say it .
she also said the only difference between white and black actresses is opportunity .
that 's all you need to succeed .
that and talent and hard work .
i ca n't say if we 'll see that on british tv soon , because we have the talent , we have the desire to work hard , what is still lacking is the opportunities .
i think that commissioning editors , some of them need to not be white .
viola davis exists because of shonda rimes - shonda rimes is a black woman putting on screen the life she leads .
that 's what we do n't have in the uk .
there is an abject lack of people of colour in power positions .
we all want to see ourselves on screen , that 's the difference in america - you have people of colour who can actually make that happen because they have the power to do so .
i 'm one of the producers on captive - for me to produce a film in the uk would be an uphill battle .

guardian contributor davidoyelowo 24 september 2015 12:21pm we have a huge amount of talent in the uk in front of the camera , we just need more people of colour as decision makers , and those who greenlight projects .
monicabrown2812 asks : we have a very promising actor in our family , an 18 year old young man of african origin who has just started a drama course at university .
what 's your advice on forward steps for his professional development in this country ?
already he is thinking of going to the us .
guardian contributor davidoyelowo 24 september 2015 12:15pm every actor needs a strong foundation from which to grow .
the uk has the best actors training in the world , and doing theatre is the best place to grow as an actor before you contemplate film .
put in the time , learn as much as you can , and then follow your gut .
we 're still not making the kind of movies in the uk that give black actors the same opportunities as white actors .
my hope is that by the time you have matured as an actor , that will have changed .
if not , see you in hollywood .
iantonia asks : mr. oyelowo , what surprised you the most about when when becoming mlk ?
guardian contributor davidoyelowo 24 september 2015 12:13pm i 've been surprised at how many people now call me mlk .
iantonia asks : you 've had a fantastic past couple of years .
has something happened to you that you had only dreamed of around 10 years ago ?
metting someone , going someplace , acting a certain role ?
guardian contributor davidoyelowo 24 september 2015 12:13pm meryl streep coming up to me and being very complimentary about selma and my performance in it was truly surreal .

documents.title: `` a romantic comedy is in order . i may give jennifer aniston a call ''
text: ella1989 asks : what kind of character roles would you like to play/would have like to have played that you maybe have n't yet ?
a superhero ; an explorer set in the arctic ; a character such as jack black in school of rock maybe ?
guardian contributor davidoyelowo 24 september 2015 12:12pm the intensity of the roles i 've been playing of late seem to suggest that a romantic comedy is in order .
i may give jennifer aniston a call .

documents.title: `` i hate someone describing a performance as 'solid ' . the word solid is a word to describe a stool sample ''
text: supermanhatescomics asks : what 's been the most patronising thing someone in the film industry has said about you or a co-worker ?
guardian contributor davidoyelowo 24 september 2015 12:12pm i hate someone describing a performance i 've given as being `` solid '' .
the word solid is a word to describe a stool sample .
daniel ch asks : what makes a great actor ?
& is there anyone that you 'd like to work with that is like that ?
guardian contributor davidoyelowo 24 september 2015 12:11pm someone who is obsessed about telling the truth of humanity .
i 've already worked with him and his name is daniel day-lewis .

documents.title: `` the rule of thumb [ to get involved in ] any project is to try and work with people who are better than me and play a part that scares me ''
text: andrew jamieson asks : your cv is superb , how do you prepare emotionally and figuratively for roles defined by shorthand like a most violent year ' or jack reacher as opposed to a more intricately projective and emotive role like selma .
quick afterthought does christopher nolan really drink that much tea on set ?

guardian contributor davidoyelowo 24 september 2015 12:10pm the rule of thumb for me in any project i do is to try and work with people who are better than me , play a part that scares me , and for the project to actually have something to say about what it is to be human .
that 's all that really governs my decision to be in a movie .
liam quane asks : what was it like working with christopher nolan , what was he like as a director ?
guardian contributor davidoyelowo 24 september 2015 12:08pm working with chris nolan was like working with the albert einstein of filmmaking .
it 's an amazing thing to be around someone who is so in command of their craft .
he was an expert in every aspect of the filmmaking process , it was an awe-inspiring experience .
liam quane asks : what is the best thing a director can do for you on set ?
guardian contributor davidoyelowo 24 september 2015 12:07pm be very clear and kind about what they want .

documents.title: `` my faith dictates the roles i play in that i avoid stories or characters that glamorise or glorify darkness ''
text: ignatzratzkywatzky asks : do you like a good bellylaugh or a thoughtful smile ?
would you choose laurel and hardy over charlie chaplin ?
guardian contributor davidoyelowo 24 september 2015 12:06pm i like a good belly laugh .
i have to admit to laughing the most at seeing people fall over .
so it would have to be charlie chaplin .
and further : how much does being a born-again christian impact on your acting ?
is it a factor in why you accept particular parts and do you draw on your faith to help you realise a performance ?
guardian contributor davidoyelowo 24 september 2015 12:07pm my faith dictates the roles i play in that i avoid stories or characters that glamorise or glorify darkness .
it does n't mean i wo n't play a dark character , as long as that character is not the hero .
maschruhm asks : the empire strikes back or return of the jedi ?
guardian contributor davidoyelowo 24 september 2015 12:05pm empire strikes back .
mariocavaradossi asks : what 's the best piece of acting advice you 've ever received ?
guardian contributor davidoyelowo 24 september 2015 12:05pm acting is reacting .
or i should say : the best acting is reacting , because that 's what life is .
kele mogotsi asks : what 's your process of prepping like when you taken on a role ?
for example , how have you approached taking on sir seretse khama in a united kingdom ?
guardian contributor davidoyelowo 24 september 2015 12:04pm every role requires something different .
for playing brian nichols , the toughest thing was not judging a guy who killed four people in a day , but trying to understand him enough to be able to play him truthfully .
with seretse khama , i 'm in the process of doing all the research into who he was but after a while you have to let that go and just be present in the scene , and tell the truth .
clareyesno asks : in selma you had to be quite fat .
in captive you 're totally buff .
how did you get in shape ?
and does changing your body help you get inside the mind of the character ?
guardian contributor davidoyelowo 24 september 2015 12:03pm so , for captive i had to what are called two-a-days - gym in the morning and gym at night .
i ended up being able to bench press my body weight and a half .
and yes , it does help with getting in the headspace of the character , because i like playing characters who are not me , and being able to bench press 250 pounds is definitely not me .

documents.title: david is with us now
text: beaumont-thomas here 's his first answer , to vammyp : did you ever watch spooks after you were ( rather unfairly ) blasted in the head ?
the whole thing fell to bits when the original staff vacated - my question is , did you all leave around the same time out of choice or was everyone pushed to make way for the new characters ?
guardian contributor davidoyelowo 24 september 2015 12:02pm once matthew and keeley left i got a bit lonely .
and so i decided to follow suit .
but it was also because the show had done so well , and film directors kept saying they 'd like to work with me , so i called their bluff .

documents.title: post your questions for david oyelowo
text: before last year , david oyelowo was already a respected actor amongst brits as well as his long-running role in bbc spy drama spooks , he was the first black actor to take on a shakespearean king in a major production , playing henry vi in 2001 .
film buffs would have noted his supporting roles in the likes of lincoln , the help , and director lee daniels ' the paperboy and the butler .
but it was his portrayal of martin luther king jr in 2014 film selma that launched him to global stardom , capturing king 's dignity and oratorical fire as well as his self-doubt .

promoting the film he was forthright on civil rights , lambasting british drama for its lack of heroic black characters , and telling an interviewer this year : do n't send me your script if you want me to play the black best friend .
oyelowo 's next film is captive , playing real-life murderous fugitive brian nichols who holds a meth-addicated single mother hostage .

ahead of its opening on friday , david joins us for a live webchat at noon bst onwards on thursday 24 september post your questions for him in the comments below , and he 'll answer as many as possible .

bulletin.text: The star of Selma is now in new thriller Captive, and joined us to answer your questions, on everything from the lack of people of colour in the TV industry to wanting to do a romcom.
